data.title: Roddy Collins: Derry must forget about the cups and chase the title
data.meta_description: I loved the Candystripes job as it is so unique
data.text:
It is closing in on a decade since I got the call to manage Derry City.

I won’t lie. There was a certain appeal. Big club in a one-club city. It had a lot going for it.

Something nagged at me that day, though. In my head, I’d always thought of Derry as a cup team rather than a side that could win a league.

And that hunch was backed up when I checked out their honours list.

READ MORE - James McClean is proof of the League of Ireland's potential

They were league title winners just once when they were an Irish League team and since they came south of the border to join the League of Ireland, in the 1985/86 season, they have managed just two championships.

Think about this.

A club founded in 1928 has won just three league titles (discounting the First Division) in 95 years. Shocking.

Triumphs

They’re a Cup team. Six FAI Cups, three Irish Cups, an astonishing 11 League Cups, as well as a collection of minor cup triumphs in the City Cup, Gold Cup, Top Four Cup, is a reflection of what they are.

Glamour boys. They love the big day.

Any side can get lucky in the cup. History has shown, several times when a bad side has won a cup.

History has never given us any evidence of an inadequate team bringing home a league.

But I know why previous Derry managers have paid so much attention to Cup runs. Because it buys you time.

The thing is that once you take on that job in the Brandywell, you surrender your privacy.

Derry people make you welcome, don’t get me wrong. I felt at home in my seven months as manager.

“Yes, Roddy,” strangers would say to you as you walked down the street.

They’d stop and talk. They’d give their opinion and advice for free.

That was fine at first. Eventually, it became suffocating.

So, I can see why managers would want a cup run, even if it is the League Cup. Get a trophy, get to a final, and you get a day out for the fans.

They love that. They can have the craic, sing their songs, shout and holler and roar and feel a civic pride in their city.

And that’s fine.

But if you are a football manager, you want leagues rather than cups. You certainly don’t want a League Cup. I used to call it as useful as an egg cup. I’d never put a win in that on my CV because it didn’t matter.

Consistency comes from winning leagues.

Cups to me represent bells, whistles and frills football. They are a bit flash. The league, the nitty-gritty of having to mentally dig deep, that is what determines a player’s character.

And that is what wins you respect.

With Derry, around Dublin, what you get is a club that is admired.

They have won more FAI Cups than any other League of Ireland club since they came into the league 39 years ago.

But in terms of league titles, across the same time period, Shamrock Rovers and Dundalk have won eight each, Shels have won six, St Pat’s five, Bohs four and Cork three.

That’s a truer reflection of what they are - a honeymoon club.

They won the last League title under Felix Healy, 26 years ago.

It could be another 26 years until they win their next one.

You see the hardest thing to manage in Derry is not the board - because their chairman, Philip O’Doherty is one of the best around.

Tricky

The tricky bit is the crowd. Their city is a goldfish bowl.

They like to have locals in their team, which is understandable when you consider the city’s history, how it was under siege during The Troubles, and how it is geographically isolated.

But the reality is that provincial clubs need outside players in it.

Just look at the populations of the country’s big urban areas.

There are 1.2m people living in Dublin – just 83,000 living in Derry.

In that context, it’s impossible for them to compete with Dublin clubs for a player base unless they go outside their city walls and bring in outsiders.

I quickly realised that when I got up to Derry. I got rid of some local players and wasn’t popular for doing so.

But in my view, I was there to mould a championship-winning team, not to put together another side that could get a League Cup.

Who cares about that trophy? No one, bar the sponsors, and Derry City fans.

A fact of life is that supporters are erratic, no matter which club they follow.

It’s a side-effect of being so passionate.

But when you have such a passionate core of fans following you, so willing to express their opinion, as a manager you are going to come under pressure.

And you have to be strong.

You have to pick a player based on his performance, not his address.

In this respect, Shamrock Rovers - who Derry plays tonight - have an in-built advantage over the Candystripes.

They have a much bigger player base at their disposal.

They don’t have the travel demands placed on clubs like Derry and Cork.

For Derry, every away game is a two-hour drive, minimum. For Rovers, only six of their 36 league games this season requires a journey of longer than an hour.

Trust

So my sympathy is with Ruaidhri Higgins, the current Derry manager.

He has a hard job on his hands, and trust me, finishing second this year, so long as they end up closer to Rovers than they did last year, will be a decent season.

For the job he has is one of the toughest in Irish football.
